repnme.cdata!:
Albania and Montenegro - Lake Skhoder
            Integrated Ecosystem Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lake Skhoder Integrated
            Ecosystem Management Project for Albania and Montenegro were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately unsatisfactory; risk to
            global environment outcome was substantial; bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory; and borrower performance also
            moderately satisfactory. Some of the lessons learned
            included: preferable to finalize a project's monitoring
            and evaluation arrangements at appraisal, including
            provision of the baseline data for benchmarking progress in
            the course of implementation. Bank's client countries
            the governments and local communities have deficient
            information on the advantages and disadvantages of using
            constructed wetlands for waste water treatment, and lack
            trust in this technology. Tough decisions have to be made on
            time if a project activity significantly deviates from
            planned arrangements in terms of its substance or timeline.
            Stimulating participation of local communities and
            Non-Government Organization (NGOs) in the process of project
            supervision, monitoring, and evaluation is advisable as long
            as the rendered support is neutral and does not influence
            stakeholder opinion. Essential that arrangements for
            periodic monitoring of the planned support to the project
            from each of the expected sources of co-financing and
            parallel funding be integrated into the Monitoring and
            Evaluation (M&E) design.

repnme.cdata!:
Albania and Montenegro - Lake Skhoder
            Integrated Ecosystem Management Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Lake Skhoder
            Integrated Ecosystem Management Project for Albania and
            Montenegro is to help establish and strengthen institutional
            mechanisms for transboundary cooperation through joint
            efforts to improve sustainable management of Lake Skadar
            Shkoder. The extension is necessary to complete the
            preparation of 'legal harmonization and bilateral
            binding agreement' and the affiliated operating costs.
            This Consulting Service includes activities related to
            elaboration of laws and by-laws in Albania and Montenegro in
            accordance with European Union (EU) directives on protected
            areas and to preparation of a bilateral binding agreement
            between the Government of Albania and the Government of
            Montenegro for the protection and sustainable development of
            Lake Shkoder and Skadar watershed. The recipient approved
            the related Inception report on September 20, 2012 and will
            comment on a first draft planned to be delivered mid-October
            2012. A final report will be discussed and signed by both
            project directors during a one-day stakeholder workshop
            organized jointly in Tirana by end-November 2012. This will
            be the first extension of the project. There are no overdue
            audits for the project and previous audit reports were found
            satisfactory to the bank.
